webTitle: Tesco results - what the analysts say

fields.standfirst: Tesco has suffered its worst sales performance in decades, piling the pressure on chief executive Philip Clarke. What do the analysts say?
fields.body:
John Ibbotson, director at retail consultants Retail Vision

Despite the PR spin, Philip Clarke's turnaround plan is not working. Revamping stores with posh bakeries, Giraffe restaurants, and a paltry £200m in price cuts is not enough to address the seismic shift in UK retailing. Tesco's market share is being destroyed by the low-cost discounters, Aldi and Lidl, and, at the other end of the spectrum, Waitrose and Marks & Spencer. Another major problem is that the hypermarket model is fast becoming redundant. Nobody needs or wants a superstore any more.

Two-hundred million pounds in cuts is nothing when Asda and Morrisons are both returning £1bn to customers. Clarke's only option now is to get out the big bazooka and blow the competition away. He needs to halve his industry-leading margin of 5% and put it into price cuts, cut capital expenditure, and reduce overheads.

Louise Cooper, independent City analyst

There is no sign that the deterioration is bottoming out. The sales performance is still getting worse. And yet Tesco describes the 1Q sales in the top paragraph as "in line with last year's exit rate", which I am not even sure what it means. But it sounds like Tesco is trying to suggest that the performance is not getting worse, when clearly it is.

There are excuses aplenty for the deterioration in performance, as ever with retailers. The normal ones are the timing of Easter and weather. Tesco is not using those old chestnuts but instead using the reduction of couponing as a new excuse and the "deflationary impact of investment in lower prices" ... Investment normally refers to an asset – something with ongoing value, a machine or a computer. Something that creates sales. Clearly a price cut fits neither of these criteria. It is not an asset on the balance sheet and does not create sales – it hits sales.

Bruno Monteyne, retail analyst at Bernstein Research

We expect this quarter to represent a low point for Tesco, but no return to positive like for like [sales is] in sight. It is likely that half of the negative like for like is caused by price cuts, store disruption from revamps and less indiscriminate vouchering... Tesco has failed to adapt to the change in competition from space race to distinct-offer competition. By raising prices faster than anybody else, we think that Tesco has lost its differentiation, giving a free ride to the targeted retailers at both ends of the spectrum (value and quality). The "accelerated" strategy is unconvincing: it is still trying to be everything to everybody and the only thing that has accelerated are market share losses.

Julie Palmer, partner at business recovery firm Begbies Traynor

After delivering super profits for many years, Tesco's management let success go to their head and assumed the good times could continue forever – a major mistake. While Aldi and Lidl have carved out a customer base at the value end of the market, Asda and Sainsbury's in the middle and Waitrose and M&S at the top, Tesco's brand identity has lost its way. The group's overhaul of its shopping experience couldn't come sooner as customers have been put off by Tesco's complex multiple-buy offers and outdated stores, which are only now being upgraded ... With growing scepticism over the viability of his plans and leadership, I expect Philip Clarke has at most 12 months to prove his worth before investors demand more drastic measures.

Richard Hunter, head of equities at Hargreaves Lansdown Stockbrokers

Investors need to ponder whether Tesco is a company showing glimpses of revival given its turnaround plan, or whether it is past its sell-by date. The wider ferocity of competition is making the implementation of the plan more difficult to achieve, although the company is trying to position itself within the three largest requirements of the supermarket sector at present, in the form of price, online and convenience stores ... As Tesco continues to try to repair the decline in its market share and reputation, investors are being rewarded with a healthy 5% dividend yield which, whilst attractive in the current interest rate environment, may not be enough of a reward for patience.

Mike Dennis, consumer sector analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald

Tesco mentions that lower food prices and reduced couponing have impacted their figures more than most, even though this time last year Tesco's sales were held back both by the transfer of store general merchandise sales online and the equine DNA impact on chilled and frozen food lines. Our view is that Tesco's core 482 superstores remain vulnerable in undifferentiated categories where discounters have made considerable inroads. The key concern now is that if UK [like-for-like] sales growth rates continue at this level then management might need to consider cutting capital investment again ... Investors should be questioning management's strategy and why the prior year's UK investment has led to falling sales.

Helal Miah, investment research analyst at The Share Centre:

Tesco is suffering at the expense of high end retailers and discounters, and today's figures are likely to leave a sour taste in the mouth of its investors. But Tesco is not on its own. Morrisons too has seen its profit margins under pressure, with the two dragging down the performance of the UK listed firms in the sector. It's clear that Tesco's turnaround has some distance to go yet, and investors will be watching carefully for the impact of its price-slashing policy and store-revamps on its bottom line for the remainder of the year.

Jonathan Jackson, head of equities at Killik & Co

Although Tesco continues to see a positive contribution from its transformation programme, performance in the UK remains subdued, while concerns persist over the group's ability to generate attractive returns overseas. We believe the strategic reallocation of capital away from large out-of-town stores towards convenience stores and online channels is the right one, but the process is slow and is occurring at a time of intense competition in the grocery market and rapidly shifting consumer shopping habits. The story remains one of long-term term recovery, with plenty of execution risks and, as a result, the outlook for future profitability is uncertain. The shares currently trade on 11x consensus 2015 earnings. Although in the face of an ongoing subdued trading environment, the shares may struggle to perform in the near term, the 4.7% dividend yield continues to provide support.

Espirito Santo analysts

We think Tesco remains a fixable business ... but we think Tesco trading in the UK will remain subdued over the near-term and think UK margins could fall closer to zero in the medium term. We argue a turnaround at Tesco could take another five years if near-term lateral thinking is not implemented.

It's clear that Tesco's turnaround has some distance to go yet, and investors will be watching carefully for the impact of its price-slashing policy and store-revamps on its bottom line for the remainder of the year. Jonathan Jackson, head of equities at Killik & Co Although Tesco continues to see a positive contribution from its transformation programme, performance in the UK remains subdued, while concerns persist over the group's ability to generate attractive returns overseas. We believe the strategic reallocation of capital away from large out-of-town stores towards convenience stores and online channels is the right one, but the process is slow and is occurring at a time of intense competition in the grocery market and rapidly shifting consumer shopping habits. The story remains one of long-term term recovery, with plenty of execution risks and, as a result, the outlook for future profitability is uncertain. The shares currently trade on 11x consensus 2015 earnings. Although in the face of an ongoing subdued trading environment, the shares may struggle to perform in the near term, the 4.7% dividend yield continues to provide support. Espirito Santo analysts We think Tesco remains a fixable business ... but we think Tesco trading in the UK will remain subdued over the near-term and think UK margins could fall closer to zero in the medium term. We argue a turnaround at Tesco could take another five years if near-term lateral thinking is not implemented.

fields.trailText: Tesco has suffered its worst sales performance in decades, piling the pressure on chief executive Philip Clarke. What do the analysts say?
